docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER steering the county through a series of health crises -- including an increase in tuberculosis cases in 1997 and 1998, a rubella epidemic in 1998 and an outbreak of West Nile-like encephalitis virus this summer -- Dr. Harold N. Adel, the county's health commissioner, has announced his retirement, effective Jan. 31. Citing the lure of his grandchildren, his cello and his hiking boots, Dr. Adel, 69, said his decision to step down was ''one of the most difficult decisions I have ever made.''
docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Harold N Adel, health commissioner of Westchester County, NY, who at age 69 has announced his retirement, effective, Jan 31; he comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a late October morning, Robert Alexander Mundell sat Buddha-like amid stylish clutter in his Claremont Avenue apartment, two blocks from Columbia University in Manhattan. The magic moment when, amid fairy-tale pomp, he will receive from the King of Sweden the heavy gold medal engraved with Alfred Nobel's stern profile was still weeks away. But life had already changed profoundly for Mr. Mundell, 67, the flamboyant Canadian-born economist whose ideas paved the way for the euro, the European currency. Since the announcement of the prize two weeks earlier, The Wall Street Journal had already described him as more important than Keynes, a television network had filmed a documentary on his life and 3,000 e-mail messages had clogged his ''in'' box. Invitations were pouring in so fast on this particular morning that his wife, Valerie Natsios, desperate for the last hour to take a shower, couldn't leave the phone: It wouldn't stop ringing.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Pataki Seeks a Trade-Off With Democrats to Cut Medicaid'' (news article, Nov. 28):
docs.abstract: Letter from Joy Elwell questions why health insurance companies contracting with New York State to administrate Medicaid benefits are permitted to deny reimbursement to nurse practitioners (Nov 28 article) (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Pataki Seeks a Trade-Off With Democrats to Cut Medicaid'' (news article, Nov. 28):

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has devised a plan to spend about $100 million a year in tobacco settlement money to extend health care insurance to 125,000 middle-class and working-poor residents, and has been shopping the plan around to the general approval of hospitals, doctors and insurers. The plan would cover working people who earn too much to qualify for federal Medicaid assistance, but too little to buy their own insurance or to pay their share of coverage offered by employers. The Whitman administration says it would all but eliminate the state's ballooning charity care bill and put poor people who now use the emergency room for the most expensive kind of treatment into a managed care program.

headline.main: Whitman Offers Health Care Plan Using Tobacco Money

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Todd Whitman proposes spending about $100 million a year of the $300 million a year that New Jersey will receive from Federal liability settlement with tobacco industry to extend health care insurance to 125,000 middle-class and working residents who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid assistance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Outsider At Box Office What happened to ''The Insider''? The drama, directed by Michael Mann, one of the best-reviewed films of the year, also stirred plenty of news coverage because of a true-life story that dealt with a ''60 Minutes'' producer who persuaded Jeffrey Wigand, a tobacco industry whistle-blower, to appear on the television program and reveal that cigarette companies knew that smoking was addictive and dangerous. Bowing to pressure, CBS's ''60 Minutes'' initially failed to broadcast the interview.

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Senator Bill Bradley today accused Vice President Al Gore of distorting his record on health care and Social Security, asserting that Mr. Gore was trying to divide the Democratic Party ''to score a few political points.'' In a speech before a group of black state legislators, Mr. Bradley made one of his most strenuous rebuttals yet against Mr. Gore's assertions that Mr. Bradley had supported policies that would hurt black people and the elderly. The two men are vying for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline.main: Bradley Rebuts Gore on Health Care and Social Security

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley, in speech to National Black Caucus of State Legislators, accuses Vice Pres Al Gore of distorting his record on health care and Social Security; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation's biggest insurance companies say they are changing their tactics as they face a surging backlash against managed care. Hoping to blunt the attack in Congress and the states, which has upset investors and depressed stocks of managed care companies, some insurers have eliminated or cut back on unpopular rules. They no longer require prior approvals for diagnostic tests or admission to a hospital, or referrals by a gatekeeper doctor for consultations with specialists.
docs.abstract: Some of nation's biggest insurance companies are changing their tactics as they face surging backlash against managed care; say they hope to blunt attack in Congress and states, which has upset investors and depressed stocks of managed care companies; they have eliminated or cut back on unpopular rules; no longer require prior approvals for diagnostic tests or admission to hospital, or referrals by gatekeeper doctor for consultations with specialists; employers and economists are concerned that relaxing these mainstays of cost restraint may unleash new round of inflation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Al Gore used to be a stick-to-the-script kind of guy. Lots of mind-numbing facts about the gross domestic product. But since he revamped his campaign two months ago after a slide in the polls, Mr. Gore has also revamped himself and thrown out the script of his standard stump speech. Now, the vice president is trying to appeal to real people by portraying himself as a real person, too. He does not make full-blown speeches; he chats. He wanders into living rooms to talk with 30 people or into school gymnasiums to talk with 300 and conducts Oprah-style discussions, which he calls open meetings. He sometimes relies on stock answers to convey his positions on the issues: He wants to resubmit the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty that the Senate recently rejected. He wants to bring ''revolutionary change'' to public schools. He wants to give health insurance to all children. [Excerpts, Page A28.]

headline.main: THE SPEECH -- Gore's Open Meetings; Gore Is Using New Medium To Convey Message: Himself

docs.abstract: Al Gore, campaigning in New Hampshire, has revamped his approach, abandoning scripted speeches in favor of chats and what he calls open meetings and portraying self as real person; is talking more about own life; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Vice President Al Gore's remarks on Nov. 19 as he met with about 60 people in a home in Keene, N.H., as transcribed by The New York Times. As he usually does, Mr. Gore made an opening statement and then took questions. The latter questions are condensed. I was raised myself in a family that taught me and my sister the virtues of public service. My mother was born a poor girl in West Tennessee at a time when poor girls were not supposed to dream. But she dreamed of a day when men and women would be equal. Worked her way through school. Worked her way through college. Took her blind sister, my Aunt Thellie, to college with her and read lessons and took notes for both of them. That was an experience that deepened her and shaped her life and, incidentally, tomorrow I'm doing a major announcement on disabilities and I'm doing an event here on policies toward Americans with disabilities. . . .

headline.main: At a Meeting With Voters, Gore Talks About His Plans, His Family and Himself

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been known for some time that medical errors are a major cause of death and suffering in the United States. Now the Institute of Medicine, the medical arm of the National Academy of Sciences, has called for a new federal office to protect patients and said Congress should require all health care providers to report mistakes that cause serious injury or death.
docs.abstract: Analysis of call by National Academy of Sciences's Institute of Medicine for steps to protect patients from medical errors; notes proposals, hailed by many health-related organizations and consumer groups, have raised concerns about added government involvement in personal health care and about patient confidentiality (M)
